results.title: Living Tomorrow : Intermediate Technology (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bob Thorpe, Ken Ashton and Mike Murray
results.brief_description: Our modern high tech. society endlessly devours the landscape, yet the English intermediate technology group, Living Tomorrow, is determined that the developing world should not waste its precious resources in the same way. Demonstrates some of the developments in intermediate technology for use in both the first and third worlds.

results.title: Living together
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Dealing with changes in the physical, social, cultural, political and economic spheres of Australian life. Each program is made up of short sequences from films and videos stored in the archives of Film Australia. This program looks at the individual and society, discrimination, resolving differences between individuals and groups in our society, working together in groups for a variety of purposes and society in change. Presented by Annette Shun Wah

results.title: Living things are everywhere
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses the story of a young boy’s discovery of the variety of living things to be found along a river bank and in the woods to explain that living things may be discovered almost anywhere and to stimulate interest in the study of plant and animal relationships.

results.title: Living stone
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and John Feeney
results.brief_description: This film shows the inspiration, often related to belief in the supernatural, behind Inuit sculpture. The Inuit’s approach to the work is to release the image he sees imprisoned in the rough stone. The film centres on an old legend about the carving of the image of a sea spirit to bring food to a hungry camp. Photographed at Cape Dorset, Boffin Island with Inuit stone carvers of Kingait and Kangiyak. Award winning documentary.

results.creator_credit: ACI Films and United World Films

results.title: Living Room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. “Home is where to sleep” - Why do people live where they do? “Home is an extension of your personality” - Do people have a choice in the way they live? What does “home” mean? A photographic mosaic of faces and places, “Living Room” reveals surprising values and attitudes.
results.description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. “Home is where to sleep” - Why do people live where they do? “Home is an extension of your personality” - Do people have a choice in the way they live? results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.
